Situation1: Their partner is going through a serious personal crisis and relies on them for consistent emotional reassurance and presence.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story: I stood in the crowded polling station, my phone buzzing in my pocket. My partner’s messages came in rapid succession—she was having another panic attack, her words desperate and pleading for me to come home. I could almost hear her voice trembling, and I knew she needed me, needed the calm I tried to bring her when the world felt too heavy. But here I was, a voter, and the election official’s voice cut through the noise, calling for everyone with last names A–M to move to the new line. My last name started with B. The new line was longer, slower, but the official’s instructions were clear. I felt the weight of duty—civic responsibility on one side, the person I loved most on the other. People around me shuffled, some grumbling, but I stood frozen, torn between following the rules and rushing home to hold my partner’s hand. My heart pounded as I tried to decide which role I owed more in this moment, feeling the pressure of both expectations closing in.
